OpenRico

February 18th, 2007 · No Comments

I went to the Austin on Rails user group meeting Tuesday night where the lead developer for the OpenRico javascript library was giving a talk on OpenRico. OpenRico is a javascript library like scriptaculous which adds a lot of animation and other neat effects to web application HTML interfaces. That’s not the point of this posting though. His “talk” was a disaster. This fellow is an engineer with many years experience and yet he just aimlessly rambled for an hour, wasting everyone’s time. Here’s a few suggestions for him and anyone else going to give a talk:

1. Have an outline of your talk

Can you describe the point of your talk in one sentence? Can you give a list of subtopics you are going to expound on to flesh out your talk? Remember your high school English: “one opening paragraph, three expository paragraphs and one conclusion paragraph”? The principle is exactly the same.

2. Have supporting material

Create Powerpoint slides. Create code samples or a demo. Show something that explains, supports or expands your current topic of discussion.

3. Be prepared

In addition to (1) and (2), be ready to talk at the appointed time. In this case, the guy was doing development right before the talk, had a zillion windows open and nothing organized. Ideally you shouldn’t require power or network access so we don’t have to sit for 5 minutes while you find an outlet, get the wireless network key, open your various presentation materials, etc.
